title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as SEC. 30B. Private Land Conservation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows eligible farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the amount that would be allowed as a deduction for a qualified conservation contribution. The maximum credit for any taxable year is $360,000, with a special rule for joint returns. The tax credit under the "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" for joint returns is allocated equally between spouses. All members of the same controlled group of corporations are treated as one taxpayer. The credit allowed for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax reduced by other credits. The tax credit for eligible farmers or ranchers is calculated by subtracting the regular tax reduced by credits from the tentative minimum tax. An eligible farmer or rancher is defined as an individual or C corporation with at least 60% of gross income from farming. Special rules apply, including asset value limits for corporations. The tax credit for eligible farmers or ranchers is subject to special rules, including an asset value limit of $20,000,000 for corporations. Taxpayers must elect the application of this section for each taxable year, and once made, the election is irrevocable. Additionally, no deduction under section 170 is allowed for a qualified conservation contribution if the taxpayer elects to take the credit for such contribution during a 15-taxable-year period. Any excess credit in a taxable year can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The excess credit in a taxable year can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The amendments in Sec. 30B apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. Sec. 3 increases the charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. Sec. 3 increases the charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form, treating them as individuals for qualified conservation contributions. This amendment also includes a conforming amendment for eligible farmers or ranchers. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under a qualified conservation easement by amending section 2031(c)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment applies to estates of decedents who pass away after the enactment of this Act.
